Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2009 08:17PM bennetts1 wrote: Hey Tennessee ladies!  I just found this thread.    I live in a small rural community in northwest Tennessee.  I was diagnosed with breast cancer in June of 2008 and have gone through chemo, a mastectomy and radiation.  I traveled to Vanderbilt to receive my treatments.  I still go to Vanderbilt every 3 months for a check-up with my oncologist.  Currently, I am researching for reconstruction.  I am wanting to have DIEP, but have not found any surgeons in Tennessee qualified to do the procedure.  Today, I am looking into going to South Carolina to Dr. Marga Massey.  I am waiting to hear from my insurance company to see if they will pay.  I was excited when I found this thread.  Hope the hear back from my Tennessee friends!

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2011 09:34AM bennetts1 wrote: My oncologist put me on Prilosec, 1 a day, but up to 2 a day if needed when I took AC.  I also took Emend, Decaderon and zofran.  I never had any problems with acid reflux or nausea...only mouth sores.
Posts.Title: Acid reflux with adriamycin+radiation? EnglishMajor marycecilia123

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2011 06:23PM bennetts1 wrote: Hi Kathy!  When I had my four rounds of A/C, I always had hoarseness after my treatments.  I had trouble with mouth sores and the nurse told me I probably had small sores down in my throat.  I was given Prevention Oncology Mouthrinse to gargle with three times a day.  Also, I drank hot tea, which helped a lot.  Hope your friend does well with her treatments!
Posts.Title: chemo and throat problems/hoarseness kt57 nowords

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2010 04:23AM bennetts1 wrote: I teach High School and taught throughout the entire time I took chemotherapy.  I took 4 cycles of A/C and 4 cycles of Taxol.  My infusions would be on Friday and I would then receive my Neulasta shot (only during A/C treatment) on Sunday.  I would miss school on Monday because of bone pain, but returned to the classroom on Tuesday.  My WBC never got low, and I never got sick.  I took Emend that kept me from getting sick from the treatments, and felt pretty good the entire time I took treatments.  I did tire very easily, but I found my students helped keep my spirits up and helped in my healing process.  Everyone is different and handles things differently.  You have to do what you think is right for you...but I believe teaching while taking chemo is very doable!  Best of Luck in your decision and with your treatments!
Posts.Title: newly diagnosed looking for elementary teachers AnnetteS Claire82

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2009 10:16PM bennetts1 wrote: American Breast Cares has a strapless bra now.  Style 112...Maybe you can find a dealer that sells their bras!  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Please help Megan0164 Megan0164

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2009 02:05AM bennetts1 wrote: Mouth sores are a huge pain!  If you have puss coming out, you may need to call the doctor and get on some type of antibiotic.  While I was on Chemo, I rinsed my mouth and gargled 3 to 4 times a day with a product called Prevention Oncology Mouth Rinse.  The Oncology Nurses at Vanderbilt would always give me supplies of the samples every time I went because I kept a sore throat from the chemo.  You can order it off the Internet.  It is alcohol-free, so it will not burn your mouth the way other mouth rinses do.  When I had sores in my throat, my oncologist did call me in a prescription for magic mouthwash, which is very nasty tasting, but it totally numbs your mouth...kinda like you have been to the dentist.  I would only use it when I could no longer stand the pain.  I hope you find relief soon!
Posts.Title: Major Mouth Sores/Sore Throat wickedfran kimby
